thread.title: Windjammers bit by Bulldogs in late-season showdown
thread.title_full: Windjammers bit by Bulldogs in late-season showdown

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Windjammers bit by Bulldogs in late-season showdown
text:
Windjammers bit by Bulldogs in late-season showdown Camden Hills drops third game in four tries, remains eighth in standings By Staff | Oct 03, 2015 
Rockport — The Camden Hills field hockey team has had an up-and-down season, evident by the Windjammers win-loss record, which hovers around the .500 mark with the regular season winding to a close. 
The Windjammers, who have made “some permanent changes” to their defensive lineup recently, said coach Lindsey Clement, hosted Lawrence of Fairfield on Thursday, Oct. 1, a scenario that proved to be a tall order for the hosts. 
The Bulldogs (9-2), new to Class B this year after years in Class A, earned their ninth win in 11 tries with a 5-2 decision over the Windjammers. 
Photos from this game will appear later with this story. 
Emily Daggett scored two goals for Camden Hills, one of which was assisted by Willow Grinnell. 
Leading the Lawrence offense were Lauren Watson (3 goals), Alexis Chamberlain (goal), Dominique Lewis (goal) and Lilla Tilton-Flood (assist). 
The Bulldogs led 3-2 at halftime. 
“We played a strong first half, but fell flat the second,” said coach Clement. “Most of our defense was playing out of position [in] the second half, so it allowed for no transition to offense. Lawrence was by far the fastest team we have seen. Their style of playing was lots of large drives, followed by lots of sprinting. We did a great job the first half of keeping up, but our defensive positioning hurt us.” 
While Clement said her team still needs to “iron out the wrinkles” defensively, she was pleased that her squad held the Bulldogs scoreless over the final 22 minutes. She also credited the work of Frances Pendleton, who “stopped a few shots that would have been goals otherwise.” 
“We have a lot of tough games coming up, so we have our work cut out for us,” the coach said. 
Lawrence held a 12-9 lead in shots and and a 6-3 edge in penalty corners. Jenna Stearns made seven saves in the cage for the Windjammers, while Emily Tozier made seven saves in goal for the Bulldogs. 
The Bulldogs advanced to the Eastern Class A championship game last year, but fell to Skowhegan. 
Camden Hills 9, Lincoln Academy 0 
At Newcastle Sept. 26, the Windjammer offense scored in droves en route to a lopsided win. 
Leading the offense were Molly Davee (goal, assist), Emily Daggett (2 goals, 2 assists), Hilary Merrifield (3 goals, assist), Frances Pendleton (goal), Emily Bowen (goal, assist), Sadie Mills (goal, assist), Caroline Keefe (assist), Amy Cummings (assist) and Halsey Yattaw (assist). 
Camden Hills held a 21-0 advantage in shots and a 13-2 edge in penalty corners. Jenna Stearns played in the cage for the Windjammers, while Zoew Sewall made 12 saves for the Eagles. 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class B North, Camden Hills (6-5, 24.8980 points) is eighth, while Winslow (7-2-1, 85.6378 points) is first in the 14-team region. The top 10 teams qualify for the playoffs.
